bibl.title: Twenty-fifth Biennial Report of the Warden of the State Penitentiary

respStmt.name: OCLC Online Computer Library Center Inc.

p.seg: STATE OF NEBRASKA Twenty-fifth Biennial Report OP THE Warden OF THE State Penitentiary LINCOLN. NEBRASKA To the Governor and the Board of Commissioners of State Institutions For the Biennium Ending November 30, 1918

THIRD BIENNIAL REPORT OF 434 STATE PENITENTIARY, LINCOLN NEBRASKA OFFICERS OF THE INSTITUTION W. T. Fenton Warden N. T. Harmon Deputy Warden Miss Mixxie Mirphy Matron William Kirby Steward Jamks O'Conxeij Chief Clerk I. C. Mincer, M. D Physician D. G. KA\AXAt(iH Captain of Guards Rev. Thomas A. Maxwell Chaplain Rev. Robert Morax Voluntary Catholic Chaplain C. J. McCarthy Chief Engineer OFFICERS OF THE HANDCRAFT BROOM COMPANY A. T. Johxsox Manager Eii « Mm Steixer Assistant Manager OFFICERS OF THE HANDCRAFT FURNITURE COMPANY L. M. Eastman Manager H. K. Montgomery Assistant Manager and Bookkeeper

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 435 STATE PENITENTIARY, LINCOLN, NEBRASKA To lux Excellency, Honorable Keith Xcrille. (ioremor, and to the Honorable Members of the Board of Coin - ininMionern of Mate Institutions, Henri/ denies, SUiih I. II nli in, ill, anil Ktlfieile O. Mili/jiehl (r< nth in fit 1 have the honor of submitting this, the twenty-fifth biennial report of the State Penitentiary for the period be - ginning December 1, 1916, and ending November 30, 1918. Elsewhere you will find complete financial and statistical tables covering transactions of the State Penitentiary for the period covered by this report. During this period we have remodeled the old shop buildings and installed the broom industry on state account, entirely eliminating the contract system. We converted the old gloomy workshop into clean, sanitary work rooms. Machinery was installed and all of the men who were not formerly employed are ijow at work. Our furniture in - dustry has been extended and more room made for the winding department in the brick building which was for - merly a broom shop. The old warehouse building which formerly belonged to the Lee Broom and Duster Company has been purchased, giving us ample storage room for the present time. On the lower floor of the old stone shop building we put in an up-to-date, well-equipped laundry. Our farming operations in the future will be carried on more extensively, as we came into possession last March of the 120 acres purchased. We have leased 240 acres across the road east of the institution, which we are farming this year. However, owing to the continued drought this year, our farm report will not show great profits. I might call your attention, however, tp our report on stock raising, which I think is a very good showing, considering the fact that we were cleaned out by cholera during this biennium. Our auditorium has been painted and decorated, and

436 THIRD BIENNIAL REPORT OF the dining rooms and cell houses have all undergone a thor - ough cleaning and painting. We put a new Victrola in our inmates' dining hall at a cost of $225.00. It is enjoyed very much by the inmates. It was paid for from the amusement fund which is accumulated each year by giving shows and other entertainments. Two years ago I reported all of the details of the new power plant which at that time was just being completed. During the first six months of the present biennium this new plant gave us some trouble; it was necessary to make a few changes in the line up of the equipment. Since these changes were made the entire plant has given us excellent satisfaction. The plant continues to supply the power for the capitol, governor's mansion. Orthopedic hospital. Ne - braska Home for Dependent Children and Nebraska Hospital for the Insane. During the last six months we have built a new boiler house. This is a modern, brick and steel, fire - proof structure. It was erected over the old building, and the work of putting up the new and tearing down the old was carried on in such a way that the service to the differ - ent institutions was not interrupted. The cost of this build - ing was approximately $14,000.00. Owing to the dry seasons in the past few years we were required to put down a new well and purchase a pump for same. The well is equipped with a Luitweiler double-stroke, non-pulsating pump. It has a capacity of 200 gallons a minute which the well is amply furnishing. The approxi - mate cost of the entire station is $3,000.00. The prison library under the supervision of the State Library Commission receives frequent visits from Miss Nellie Williams who has general supervision of the libraries in all of the state institutions. There are 3,600 carefully selected and classified volumes on the shelves and a complete cata - logue is given each inmate with the privilege of selecting his reading. One of the inmates acts as librarian under the supervision of the chaplain. The present assistant has been in this position eleven months and his record shows that 10,579 volumes have been read in that time; making an average of 961 volumes a month. Of this number 6,064

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 437 were fiction, and 4,515 non-fiction. The character of the reading may be seen by the report for July, 1918. Total i:<4 Thirty magazines are received on regular subscriptions and these all have a wide circulation. It is the purpose to have books read that are of a high character and to keep out such reading as would not be uplifting. Our school during this period has been well attended and under the able supervision of Mr. James O'Connell much has been accomplished in the way of education. The moral atmosphere of the institution is the very best; the religious work having been looked after in an able manner by Rev. Thomas Maxwell and Father Moran, and the several Sunday school teachers who visit our institution every Sunday. Our population has decreased during the present bien - nium by about 25 per cent. The inmates are behaving well, working hard and have saved enough of their earnings to enable them to contribute the following amounts to the support of the war: Subscriptions to Liberty Bonds $3,500.0C Purchase of Thrift Stamps 1.400.0C In addition to this the men of this institution are now providing the funds to care for thirteen French orphans. All of these subscriptions and donations were made cheer - fully; the only regret being that the subscribers were not able to do more to help win the war. In conclusion, I wish to thank my worthy deputy for General works 22 Philosophy 68 Religion 48 Sociology 40 1'hilology Natural science 22 30 I'seful arts 47 Fine arts 32 Literature 55 History 174 Fiction 656

438 THIRD BIENNNIAL REPORT OF his assistance in carrying on the important work of the in - stitution. And all my other co-workers, 1 wish to thank for their able assistance during the past two years. I wish to thank the Honorable Board for the assistance and uniform courtesy always extended to me. Very respectfully submitted. W. T. Frntok. Wo nhn. Lincoln, Nebraska. November 30, 1918.
